questions.question_text: What does an electric circuit mean?
hints: Think about the path for electric current
Consider components like cell, bulb, switch, wires

questions.question_text: Define the unit of current.
hints: Recall the SI unit named after a French scientist

questions.question_text: Calculate the number of electrons constituting one coulomb of charge.
hints: Use charge of one electron = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C
Divide total charge by charge per electron

questions.question_text: Name a device that helps to maintain a potential difference across a conductor.
hints: Think of a source of electrical energy
Commonly used in circuits to drive current

questions.question_text: What is meant by saying that the potential difference between two points is 1 V?
hints: Recall definition: work done per unit charge

questions.question_text: How much energy is given to each coulomb of charge passing through a 6 V battery?
On what factors does the resistance of a conductor depend?
Will current flow more easily through a thick wire or a thin wire of the same material, when connected to the same source? Why?
hints: Resistance is inversely proportional to area

questions.question_text: Let the resistance of an electrical component remains constant while the potential difference across the two ends of the component decreases to half of its former value. What change will occur in the current through it?
hints: If V halves, I also halves (R constant)

questions.question_text: Why are coils of electric toasters and electric irons made of an alloy rather than a pure metal?
hints: They don't oxidize easily at high temperatures

questions.question_text: Use the data in Table 11.2 to answer the following – (a) Which among iron and mercury is a better conductor? (b) Which material is the best conductor?
hints: Check values in table: silver has lowest resistivity

questions.question_text: Draw a schematic diagram of a circuit consisting of a battery of three cells of 2 V each, a 5 Ω resistor, an 8 Ω resistor, and a 12 Ω resistor, and a plug key, all connected in series.
hints: Battery: three cells in series = 6 V total

questions.question_text: Redraw the circuit of Question 1, putting in an ammeter to measure the current through the resistors and a voltmeter to measure the potential difference across the 12 Ω resistor. What would be the readings in the ammeter and the voltmeter?
hints: Ammeter in series, voltmeter in parallel across 12 Ω
Calculate total resistance, then current using Ohm's law

questions.question_text: Judge the equivalent resistance when the following are connected in parallel – (a) 1 Ω and 10⁶ Ω, (b) 1 Ω and 10³ Ω, and 10⁶ Ω.
hints: For very large resistance in parallel, equivalent is close to smaller resistance

questions.question_text: An electric lamp of 100 Ω, a toaster of resistance 50 Ω, and a water filter of resistance 500 Ω are connected in parallel to a 220 V source. What is the resistance of an electric iron connected to the same source that takes as much current as all three appliances, and what is the current through it?
hints: Find total current through all three appliances
Use I = V/R for each, then sum
Equivalent resistance R = V / total current

questions.question_text: What are the advantages of connecting electrical devices in parallel with the battery instead of connecting them in series?
hints: If one fails, others still work
Devices can draw different currents as needed

questions.question_text: How can three resistors of resistances 2 Ω, 3 Ω, and 6 Ω be connected to give a total resistance of (a) 4 Ω, (b) 1 Ω?
hints: For 4 Ω: combine parallel and series

questions.question_text: What is (a) the highest, (b) the lowest total resistance that can be secured by combinations of four coils of resistance 4 Ω, 8 Ω, 12 Ω, 24 Ω?
Why does the cord of an electric heater not glow while the heating element does?
hints: Cord has much lower resistance than heating element
Heating depends on I²R, so more heat in higher resistance

questions.question_text: Compute the heat generated while transferring 96000 coulomb of charge in one hour through a potential difference of 50 V.
hints: Use H = VIt or H = VQ
Convert time to seconds if needed

questions.question_text: An electric iron of resistance 20 Ω takes a current of 5 A. Calculate the heat developed in 30 s.
What determines the rate at which energy is delivered by a current?
An electric motor takes 5 A from a 220 V line. Determine the power of the motor and the energy consumed in 2 h.
hints: Energy = P × t (convert hours to seconds or use kWh)

questions.question_text: A piece of wire of resistance R is cut into five equal parts. These parts are then connected in parallel. If the equivalent resistance of this combination is R′, then the ratio R/R′ is – (a) 1/25 (b) 1/5 (c) 5 (d) 25
Which of the following terms does not represent electrical power in a circuit? (a) I²R (b) IR² (c) VI (d) V²/R
hints: Power formulas: P = VI = I²R = V²/R
IR² is not a standard power expression

questions.question_text: An electric bulb is rated 220 V and 100 W. When it is operated on 110 V, the power consumed will be – (a) 100 W (b) 75 W (c) 50 W (d) 25 W
hints: Find resistance from rating: R = V²/P

questions.question_text: Two conducting wires of the same material and of equal lengths and equal diameters are first connected in series and then parallel in a circuit across the same potential difference. The ratio of heat produced in series and parallel combinations would be – (a) 1:2 (b) 2:1 (c) 1:4 (d) 4:1
hints: For same V and t, H ∝ 1/R
Compare equivalent resistances: series = 2R, parallel = R/2

questions.question_text: How is a voltmeter connected in the circuit to measure the potential difference between two points?
hints: Voltmeter is always connected in parallel
Across the two points where PD is to be measured

questions.question_text: A copper wire has diameter 0.5 mm and resistivity of 1.6 × 10⁻⁸ Ω m. What will be the length of this wire to make its resistance 10 Ω? How much does the resistance change if the diameter is doubled?
hints: If diameter doubled, area becomes 4 times, resistance becomes 1/4

questions.question_text: The values of current I flowing in a given resistor for the corresponding values of potential difference V across the resistor are given below – I (amperes) 0.5 1.0 2.0 3.0 4.0 V (volts) 1.6 3.4 6.7 10.2 13.2 Plot a graph between V and I and calculate the resistance of that resistor.
When a 12 V battery is connected across an unknown resistor, there is a current of 2.5 mA in the circuit. Find the value of the resistance of the resistor.
hints: Convert mA to A: 2.5 mA = 0.0025 A

questions.question_text: A battery of 9 V is connected in series with resistors of 0.2 Ω, 0.3 Ω, 0.4 Ω , 0.5 Ω and 12 Ω, respectively. How much current would flow through the 12 Ω resistor?
hints: All in series, same current through each
Find total resistance, then current I = V/R_total

questions.question_text: How many 176 Ω resistors (in parallel) are required to carry 5 A on a 220 V line?
hints: Find equivalent resistance needed: R = V/I = 220/5
For n parallel resistors of R each: R_eq = R/n

questions.question_text: Show how you would connect three resistors, each of resistance 6 Ω, so that the combination has a resistance of (i) 9 Ω, (ii) 4 Ω.
hints: For 9 Ω: two in parallel (3 Ω) then in series with one (6+3=9)
For 4 Ω: two in series (12 Ω) then in parallel with one: 1/R = 1/12 + 1/6 = 1/4

questions.question_text: Several electric bulbs designed to be used on a 220 V electric supply line, are rated 10 W. How many lamps can be connected in parallel with each other across the two wires of 220 V line if the maximum allowable current is 5 A?
hints: Number of bulbs = total max current / current per bulb

questions.question_text: A hot plate of an electric oven connected to a 220 V line has two resistance coils A and B, each of 24 Ω resistance, which may be used separately, in series, or in parallel. What are the currents in the three cases?
Compare the power used in the 2 Ω resistor in each of the following circuits: (i) a 6 V battery in series with 1 Ω and 2 Ω resistors, and (ii) a 4 V battery in parallel with 12 Ω and 2 Ω resistors.
hints: (i) Find current through 2 Ω (same in series), then P = I²R
(ii) Voltage across 2 Ω = 4 V, P = V²/R

questions.question_text: Two lamps, one rated 100 W at 220 V, and the other 60 W at 220 V, are connected in parallel to electric mains supply. What current is drawn from the line if the supply voltage is 220 V?
hints: Find resistance of each: R = V²/P
Total current I = V/R_eq or sum of individual currents

questions.question_text: Which uses more energy, a 250 W TV set in 1 hr, or a 1200 W toaster in 10 minutes?
hints: Convert time to same units (hours or seconds)

questions.question_text: An electric heater of resistance 44 Ω draws 5 A from the service mains for 2 hours. Calculate the rate at which heat is developed in the heater.

Explain the following. (a) Why is the tungsten used almost exclusively for filament of electric lamps? (b) Why are the conductors of electric heating devices, such as bread-toasters and electric irons, made of an alloy rather than a pure metal? (c) Why is the series arrangement not used for domestic circuits? (d) How does the resistance of a wire vary with its area of cross-section? (e) Why are copper and aluminium wires usually employed for electricity transmission?
hints: (a) High melting point, can emit light at high temp
(b) Alloys have high resistivity, don't oxidize easily
(c) Different devices need different currents, one failure breaks circuit
